MailSpoon Documentation

Documentation for MailSpoon

You can write your documentation files in AsciiDoc as well as Markdown. Jekyll converts it to HTML using Asciidoctor, via the jekyll-asciidoc Jekyll plugin.

Here’s what code examples look like:

Some Ruby:

puts "Hello, World!"

And, of course, some Matlab:

classdef SomeClass < SomeOtherClass

  properties
    x (1,1) double = 42
    y
  end

  methods
    function this = SomeClass()
    end

    function blah(this)
      anExampleFunction(this.x)
    end
  end

end

function anExampleFunction(foo, bar)
  arguments
    foo (1,1) double
    bar string = "whatever"
  end

  fprintf('Hello, world!\n')
  fprintf('foo=%f, bar=%s\n', foo, bar)
end

That Matlab syntax highlighting currently isn’t right. It’s because Pygments, the syntax highlighter that Asciidoctor users, doesn’t have good support for modern Matlab OOP language features.

You can use "STEM" formatting to display science and engineering math markup. Inline STEM can be written like \$sqrt(4) = 2\$, and block STEM content looks like this:

\$sqrt(4) = 2\$

(To get this to work, you need to explicitly enable :stem: on each .adoc page that uses it. I’m working on figuring out how to enable it globally.)

You can include GraphViz and UML diagrams using the Asciidoctor Diagram plugin, which is enabled by default.
